objdescid.origination: Catherine Blakecolorist, Blake's wife Catherine probably added most of the coloring to the designs after her husband's death in 1827. See the introductory essay and the Editors' Notes to each object for attributions of the coloring./
objdescid.compdate: c. 1824-27The earlier date is established by fragments of an 1824 watermark on some objects; the terminal date is established by Blake's death in August 1827. It is of course possible that Blake did not begin work on his Bunyan illustrations until a year or two later than 1824. They were left incomplete at his death.

objinfo.objsize: each approximately 18.0 x 13.5 cm. for the designs in vertical format, approximately 13.5 x 18.0 cm. for the designs in horizontal format.
objinfo.leafsize: Approximately 24.0 x 19.5 cm. for the designs in vertical format, approximately 19.5 x 24.0 cm. for the designs in horizontal formatThe leaf has been trimmed close to the design in Object 3.
objinfo.medium: pencil, pen and ink, and water color
objinfo.watermark: JWHATMAN / 1824Various fragments of this watermark appear on Objects 1, 6, 14, 20-22, 27, and 28.
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneIn addition to Blake's own inscription within the design of Object 10 (see Transcription), the margins and versos of Blake's water colors bear several inscriptions in pencil, both numbers (apparently an attempt to sequence the designs) and captions or titles above and below the designs. Transcriptions are given in Butlin 829.1-19, in G. E. Bentley, Jr., "The Inscriptions on Blake's Designs to *Pilgrim's Progress*," *Blake Newsletter* 6.2 (fall 1972): 68-70, and in Sotheby's auction catalogue of 14 Nov. 1996, lot 253. With the exception of the title above the design of Object 23, these inscriptions are not shown in the Archive's reproductions. We quote Butlin's inscriptions in the Editors' Notes to each object. Butlin suggests "that some at least of the numbers may have been the work of Blake himself" and tentatively attributes the title inscription on Object 2 to Blake, but does not attribute what he calls the "usual hand" that wrote all others. Bentley, in his essay cited above, attributes all the inscriptions to Frederick Tatham, but in our view his authorship is questionable.
objinfo.framelines: 1The single frame line, contiguous with the edges of each design, surrounds all four sides on some objects but is lacking on at least one side in others.

provenance.name: Alan Parker, London (Objects 1-19, 21-29); National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C. (Object 20)
provenance.note: All twenty-nine designs possibly commissioned by Elizabeth Aders c. 1825 but only Object 20 (see record below on its provenance) retained by her; Objects 1-19, 21-29 acquired by Blake's wife Catherine upon his death in Aug. 1827; probably acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; Objects 1-19, 21-29 sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 29 April 1862, lot 187, "a series of twenty-eight designs for The Pilgrim's Progress" (£13.10s. to Richard Monckton Milnes, later Lord Houghton); by inheritance to his son, the Earl of Crewe, in 1885; sold from Crewe's collection in Dec. 1941 to the Frick Collection, New York, through the dealer M. Knoedler and Co.; offered from the Frick Collection, Sotheby's, 14 Nov. 1996, in lot 253 with Blake's water color, *The Third Temptation*, an illustration to John Milton's *Paradise Regained* (not sold); acquired shortly after the 1996 auction by Peter Parker; by inheritance to his son, Alan Parker, in 2002. Object 20 acquired by Elizabeth Aders, possibly as early as 1827 directly from Blake or from Blake's wife, Catherine, after his death in Aug. 1827; Audrey Pauncefote, possibly by inheritance; sold Sotheby's, 10 Dec. 1958, lot 72 (£1200 to the dealer Smithson acting for Lessing J. Rosenwald on behalf of the National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C.); accessioned by the National Gallery of Art in 1961.

repository.institution: National Gallery of Art, Washington, D. C. (Object 20)

desc.objtitle: John Bunyan Dreams a Dream, Object 1 (Butlin 829.1)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.1 states that the coloring was "more or less finished by [William] Blake himself." Catherine Blake may have added a few touches to the coloring. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscriptions: "1" top left, "John Bunyan dreams a dream Pilgrims Progress" below the design, and "10/6" on the verso.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A sleeping figure, presumably John Bunyan and therefore male, dominates the design, lying on a small, grassy hill. He wears a long gown with sleeves that covers his entire body, and has long, curly hair. His arms are folded under his head, supporting it as a pillow. The right arm is tucked behind the left arm and under the head, so that only the left hand is visible, and his head lies mostly on the fold of the left forearm. Bunyan's body lies slightly diagonally across the image, with his feet in the lower left corner and his head and arms just right of the center of the image. He lies on his side, facing the viewer, and his face can be fully seen. Only his right foot and leg is visible as the left leg is tucked behind the right or the hill on which Bunyan lies. Bunyan is dreaming, with the scenes of his dreams represented as an arc of vignettes superimposed on the foliage above him. The hill under Bunyan is covered in grass and other foliage, with individual tufts of grass visible. Just beneath Bunyan's knee, three ivy-like leaves are noticeable, with lines indicating vines connecting them. A group of circular leaves, shaped like a bunch of grapes, is visible below the right-most ivy-like leaf. Beneath Bunyan and to the right, a sleeping lion lies in profile inside a small cave, embankment, or hole in the foliage under the hill. He is male, as indicated by the curly-haired mane, and his prominently large head is to the left, resting on the ground between his forepaws, although only the left one is visible. His tufted tail lies at his left side, and the paw of his left hind leg is hidden behind the tail. A short, rocky cliff or embankment rises behind Bunyan, covered in leafy foliage, of at least two different types: the circular, grape-like leaves, and more triangular, pointed leaves. The foliage covers the upper portions of the plate above the cliff. Superimposed on this foliage, a rainbow-like arc of vignettes crosses the image, presumably the scenes of Christian's journey which the sleeping Bunyan dreams. The leftmost vignette consists of a walled and parapeted city gate, with a hunchbacked figure walking away from the gate to the right with his right leg back and left leg forward, bent at the knee; he carries a load on his back and appears to hold a walking stick or staff in his right hand. The next vignette to the right consists of two figures. The left-most figure stands with back to the viewer, legs outstretched with the left leg back and the right leg lunging forward, bent at the knee. The figure's left arm is raised over the head, and he appears to hold a shield in that hand above his head. The right arm is down at the figure's side, but with the hand and forearm extended forward, possibly holding a sword pointed upwards at the other figure in the vignette. This figure looks at the figure to his right who faces the first in an antagonistic stance. Its legs are spread wide and arms raised over the head at 135 degrees, so that the figure makes an X-shaped stance. The figure has a long, bushy mane of hair and beard which obscures the head. In the next vignette to the right (at about the midpoint of the image horizontally), a figure stands in profile under a large arch. The figure appears to be wearing a gown. A faint path or road may run under the arch and into the background of the vignette. A circle at chest-level of the figure is possibly the head of a second, smaller, gowned figure standing in front of the first from the perspective of the viewer. The final vignette is at the upper right corner of the image. This vignette is not as clear as the others, but appears to consist of several spire-like structures, with a few figures standing below them, indicated by three circular head-like shapes. Beams of light emanate from this vignette down towards the sleeping head of Bunyan.

desc.objtitle: Christian Reading in His Book, Object 2 (Butlin 829.2)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.2 states that the coloring is "by [William] Blake." Catherine Blake may have reinforced some of the dark areas. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscriptions: "2—I saw a man clothed in rags with his face from his own house a Book in his hand, & a great burden on his back" top right, and "Christian begins his pilgrimage" below the design. Butlin tentatively attributes the inscription top right to Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christian flees the City of Destruction, reading his book, most likely the Bible, as he goes. Christian is shoeless and dressed in ragged, high-waisted pants or tights and shirt, with ragged holes that reveal a muscular physique underneath. He stands in stride, left leg forward, right leg back and both bent at the knee, but hunched over because of a bulging load above his neck, shoulders, and upper back. This load appears to be tied around his waist by a strap, but also appears attached to him at the shoulders. His long, curly hair flows past his neck under the load, and his head is bent so that he faces downward, looking at the book in his hands. His mouth is slightly open, and his furrowed brow suggests a melancholic or despairing gaze. His arms are bent at 90 degrees at the elbow, and he holds the open book in his hands. He casts a dark shadow on the flat land on which he walks. The city behind him and on the left half of the image consists of square stone walls with some taller square buildings and spires rising up above them. Directly behind Christian and to the right are distant trees of unidentifiable type, represented by a couple clear trunks and bushy foliage. A sloped hill rises above the trees in the background, and another domed building can be seen behind the hill, although partially obscured. At the top of the plate, a dark, billowing cloud, or possibly smoke, fills the sky. A few tongues of flame reach out from behind the cloud, in the middle of the plate above Christian’s back, and at the left of the plate right above the spires of the city.

desc.objtitle: Christian Meets Evangelist, Object 3 (Butlin 829.3)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.3 attributes the coloring to William Blake but adds that "the colouring of the sky near Evangelist's extended right hand seems to have been reinforced." The reinforcing may have been by Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following verso inscription: "3" altered from "2" followed by "Evangelist gives Christian the roll".

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christian and another figure meet just outside the gate of the City of Destruction. Christian stands to the left with his body facing forward towards the viewer. His head is turned slightly towards the other figure, but his full face is still visible. He looks at the second figure, and his mouth is slightly open, as if in an expression of surprise. His long hair is visible on either side of his head and neck, flowing down behind his shoulders, and a few individual flame-like locks of hair stand on end. He is shoeless and wears ragged, high-waisted pants or tights and a tight-fitting shirt which reveals a muscular physique underneath. His load is visible, bulging behind his head, neck, and right shoulder. His arms are tight against his side, but bent at the elbow so that forearm and hands are raised. His palms face out towards the viewer, and his fingers are spread. He stands midstride with his left leg forward and that foot planted firmly on the ground. The left calf and knee are particularly muscular. His right leg is back, standing on tiptoe with only the first two toes on the ground. The second and clearly older figure, presumably Evangelist, stands in profile on the right side of the image. Only the left side of his face is visible as he looks down at Christian. He has long, curly hair and possibly a beard, although it is obscured by his left shoulder. He wears a long gown with long sleeves and visible folds around his legs. His upper body is twisted slightly so that his back is partially visible, and the gown is tighter here, revealing a muscular physique underneath. His left arm is down at his side, and he holds a partially unrolled scroll in his left hand. His right arm is raised horizontally and extended behind him, and his right hand gestures towards that direction, fingers spread. He is perhaps gesturing towards a beam of light above the large mountains in the background below his hand. He also appears to be midstride, although not as dramatic a stride as Christian's. His right leg is not visible under the folds of the gown, but his left leg is, and it is extended slightly back. The foot protrudes from the hem of the gown, with toes on the ground but heel raised. A large, arched gate stands directly to the left of and behind Christian. The gate is pointed in a Gothic style with three individual arches stacked on top of each other in tiers. The gate appears to be open, as indicated by the absence of doors. Christian and Evangelist stand on a flat, grassy, stretch of land in the foreground, but the background behind them is filled with various hills, buildings, forests, and mountains. Moving from foreground to background, the first level behind and to the right of Evangelist is a dark forest, as indicated by three trunk-like shapes, sitting on a grassy rise. Behind or slightly blended into these trees is a dark sloping hill that falls to the left towards the center of the image. The next level behind this hill is another, irregular hill that slopes from behind the gate on the left side of the image downward towards the middle of the image, behind the first hill. Behind both of these hills, a few structures are visible in the space between Christian and Evangelist and between Christian's legs. The left-most structure (between Christian's legs) consists of a square wall surrounding a square building with a spire, perhaps a church. The next structure to the right is spherical and protrudes from behind the wall, although the type of building is not clear. The final structure is a trilithon whose left vertical stone and most of the horizontal stone are fully visible, with the right vertical stone hidden behind Evangelist. These structures are presumably part of the City of Destruction. The space above these structures is filled with a red cloud, ending in a small tongue of flame just to the right of Evangelist; therefore, the city seems to be on fire, paralleling depictions in other objects. Behind the city, a mountain rises from the left to the right, with one peak directly below Evangelist's right hand, and another peak just to the right of and below the first. Bright beams of light are visible in the sky behind the second peak, perhaps the rising or setting sun or some source of fire. A few dark, smoky clouds hover around the light source and above both peaks. This mountain is perhaps the volcanic Mount Sinai. Another mountain rises behind this one from the middle of the image to the left, mostly obscured by Christian and terminating behind the large gate on the left edge of the image.

desc.objtitle: Christian Pursued by Obstinate and Pliable, Object 4 (Butlin 829.4)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.4 states that the design is "finished, but not by [William] Blake." We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "4" altered from "3" followed by "Obstinate and Pliable follow him" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christian is shown fleeing the City of Destruction, pursued by two figures, Obstinate and Pliable. Christian dominates the lower half of the image, standing at the bottom of a series of grassy hills. Christian is shoeless and dressed in worn, high-waisted pants or tights and shirt, with ragged holes that reveal a muscular physique underneath. He stands in stride, with his right leg bent at the knee and left leg extended backward, but hunched over to the point that his right knee touches his chest because of a bulging load above his neck, shoulders, and upper back. This load appears to be supported and bound to Christian by a strap extending across his chest from his lower right torso to his left shoulder. His long, curly hair stands on end in flame-like locks around his head. He faces forward with his mouth slightly open and brow furrowed, suggesting a melancholic or despairing gaze. His arms are raised horizontally and spread wide with hands open and flat, fingers spread, and palms out toward the viewer. Two figures chase after Christian, also in stride, on a grassy hill in the middle ground behind him and on the right side of the image. These figures are presumably Obstinate and Pliable, although it is unclear which is which. The right figure stands slightly in front of the left figure, facing forward with left leg straight and right leg extended backward. He wears a one-piece tight-fitting garment which cuts off at the knees. His arms are raised vertically with fingers spread and palms facing up. His short, curly hair flows behind him, and his mouth appears slightly open. The left figure stands slightly behind and obscured by the right figure, but he also faces forward with one arm raised vertically and mouth slightly open. He stands with left leg forward and right leg extended back, but it is unclear if he is wearing any garments. The City of Destruction fills the upper half of the image on a series of hills extending into the background. From front to back, the first hill slopes downward from left to right across the image, with a tapered, cylindrical structure on the left side (similar to a cone with the point removed), and three or four square buildings with pitched roofs on the left side behind Obstinate and Pliable. The two left-most buildings in this group have dark pentagonal openings on one side, and the right one of the two has a dark roof. A Gothic church with tall steeple spires stands on the hill above these buildings in the center of the image. On the level behind and to the left of the church sits another cylindrical building in the center of the image and a dark walled and turreted castle on a dark hill to the left. Another faint structure stands on the far left of the image next to this castle, perhaps a pine tree or some other cross-like structure. At the right and left edges of the plate, red billowing clouds or smoke rise into darker ones that fill the sky at the top of the image; a break in the clouds reveals a blue sky behind the topmost buildings.

component.illusobjdesc: Christian is shown fleeing the City of Destruction, pursued by two figures, Obstinate and Pliable. Christian dominates the lower half of the image. Christian is shoeless and dressed in worn, high-waisted pants or tights and shirt, with ragged holes that reveal a muscular physique underneath. He stands in stride, with his right leg bent at the knee and left leg extended backward, but hunched over to the point that his right knee touches his chest because of a bulging load above his neck, shoulders, and upper back. This load appears to be supported and bound to Christian by a strap extending across his chest from his lower right torso to his left shoulder. His long, curly hair stands on end in flame-like locksaround his head. He faces forward with his mouth slightly open and brow furrowed, suggesting a melancholic or despairing gaze. His arms are raised horizontally and spread wide with hands open and flat, fingers spread, and palms out toward the viewer.

Two figures chase after Christian, also in stride, on a grassy hill in the middle ground behind him and on the right side of the image. These figures are presumably Obstinate and Pliable, although it is unclear which is which. The right figure stands slightly in front of the left figure, facing forward with left leg straight and right leg extended backward. He wears a one-piece tight-fitting garment which cuts off at the knees. His arms are raised vertically with fingers spread and palms facing up. His short, curly hair flows behind him, and his mouth appears slightly open.

He faces forward with one arm raised vertically and mouth slightly open. He stands with left leg forward and right leg extended back, but it is unclear if he is wearing any garments.

The City of Destruction fills the upper half of the image on a series of hills extending into the background. From front to back, the first hill slopes downward from left to right across the image, with a tapered, cylindrical structure on the left side (similar to a cone with the point removed), and three or four square buildings with pitched roofs on the left side behind Obstinate and Pliable. The two left-most buildings in this group have dark pentagonal openings on one side, and the right one of the two has a dark roof. Another faint structure stands on the far left of the image next to this castle, perhaps a pine tree or some other cross-like structure.

At the right and left edges of the plate, red billowing clouds or smoke rise into darker ones that fill the sky at the top of the image; a break in the clouds reveals a blue sky behind the topmost buildings.

The figures and structure in this image stand on a series of rolling grassy hills extending from foreground to background.

desc.objtitle: Christian in the Slough of Despond, Object 5 (Butlin 829.5)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.5 states that "Pliable seems originally to have been nude but is now clothed in blue and pink. The clouds look dead and have probably been worked over, as have the outlines of the figures." We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "5" altered from "3" followed by "Pliable leaves Xtian in the Slough of Despond" below the design.

illusdesc.illustration:
Christian and Pliable are caught in the Slough of Despond outside the City of Destruction. The Slough, a dark, murky body of water, perhaps a river or lake, takes up the bottom third of the image. A few small waves break on the surface of the water. Christian is shown in profile in the lower-left corner of the image, doubled over on his hands and knees, crawling through the Slough. His hands, forearms, knees, and lower legs are all below the surface of the water, but faintly visible. His right arm is slightly ahead of his left, and his left leg is extended backward. The outline of his right leg is barely visible, bent at the knee and forward. His head, torso, upper arms, buttocks, and thighs are above the surface. He wears tight-fitting clothes, including a long-sleeved shirt and pants or tights, revealing a muscular body underneath. His load rests on his shoulders and back, tied to his body by a strap around his chest. He faces downward, with his long, curly hair hanging into the water. On the right side of the image, Pliable crawls out of the Slough onto the shore. He faces away from the viewer, toward the City of Destruction in the background, although his head is turned to the left so we can see his face in profile. His left leg is forward and bent 90 degrees at the knee, with his foot on the shore. His right leg extends backward into the water, breaking the surface at the thigh with the lower leg underwater and not visible. His arms are spread on either side of his body, bent 90 degrees at the elbows with his palms flat and on the ground, as if pulling himself out of the water. He wears skintight clothing, including a shirt and pants or tights, revealing a muscular body underneath. He looks off towards the left, perhaps at the city in the distance or at a large black cloud or smoke. His short, flame-like hair falls back onto his neck. A large, billowing black cloud or smoke runs across the image from the lower-left to the upper-right edges of the plate, dominating the sky in the upper left corner. The City of Destruction sits atop a few grassy hills and ridges in the background, consisting of several distinct buildings behind a large stone wall. From right to left, those buildings are a domed structure with a cross on top; a square building with two tall square towers, one with a large door-like opening; six short spires surrounding one tall spire, perhaps from a church; a cylindrical building with a small, low, barely-visible dome beneath; and a square building with two tall, skinny towers, perhaps the turreted castle from earlier plates.

desc.objtitle: Christian Drawn out of the Slough by Help, Object 6 (Butlin 829.6)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.6 states that the design was "finished by another hand," presumably Catherine Blake's. We attribute the coloring to her. Butlin also quotes the following marginal and verso inscriptions: "6" altered from "7" above the design, "Help lifts Christian out of the Slough of Despond" below the design, and "'Help' lifts Xtian out of the Slough of Despond" on the verso. There may be fragments of an undecipherable inscription on the sun upper right just above the splotchy red coloring.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Help stands in the middle of the image, pulling Christian out of the Slough of Despond. The Slough is depicted as a dark body of water spread across the bottom of the image, perhaps a river or lake. Small waves break on the surface, especially around Christian's body. Help is standing but hunched over at the waist, reaching down to lift Christian. He stands with his body facing forward and his right leg slightly in front of his left. His arms reach straight down as he grabs Christian's arms above the elbow to pull him out of the water. Folds of fabric flowing down to the ground on either side of him suggest that he is wearing a cloak, and he appears to wear other skintight garments covering his legs and arms, as indicated by the hemlines on his right ankle and both wrists. The garment may instead be a long, semi-transparent gown. Muscular shoulders and thighs can be seen through the garments. He has short, curly hair and beard and looks downward at Christian, although his head is angled up slightly so that his full face is seen. Christian is almost entirely submerged in the Slough, with only his upper back, head, and arms above the surface. His body faces away from the viewer, but he looks up towards Help with his head bent back so his face is visible, and with his flame-like hair falling back onto his shoulders and upper back. His arms are fully extended vertically above him, reaching towards Help, with his hands opened and palms turned up. The fingers of his right hand appear to be spread. He also wears a garment, as indicated by hemlines at his wrists. Help stands on a grassy shore, and a series of ridges rises above him in the background of the image, with a serpentine path curving behind him towards the left edge, then turning towards the center and terminating behind Help. Large, leafy trees stand on either side of the image, with three prominent trunks to the left of the path and another knotty one to the right of Help. Above the trees, a dark, sloping hill or mountain falls from the left edge of the image towards the right, disappearing behind the rightmost tree. Above this tree and behind the hill spreads another flat, grassy expanse of land, with a bright red sun either rising or falling behind this horizon. Six rays emanate from the sun as beams of light into the dark sky at the top of the image. The very uppermost portion is filled with several flat, dark, overlapping clouds.

desc.objtitle: Christian Directed by Mr. Worldly-Wiseman, Object 7 (Butlin 829.7)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.7 states that "the figures and landscape have been finished by another hand," presumably Catherine Blake's. The sky may have been colored by William Blake but we attribute the coloring of the figures and landscape to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "7" over a deleted number followed by "—Mr Worldly Wiseman directs Xtian to the house of Legality, in the village of Morality" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Mr. Worldly-Wiseman, a tall, old, male figure, stands on the left side of the image. He has long hair and a long, bushy beard. He wears a loose, white gown. He stands straight with his body facing forward, although it is angled slightly so that he is not fully facing the viewer. His right arm is at his side, but bent at the elbow so the forearm and hand are hidden behind his back. His left arm is raised horizontally and extended outward, gesturing towards a fiery mountain or volcano in the background of the image. Muscular arms and upper chest are visible through his gown. His eyes look forward, instead of down towards Christian at his feet. His left foot is barely visible, sticking out from under the hem of his gown. Christian is stooped low at Mr. Worldly-Wiseman's feet. His left leg is bent forward 90 degrees at the knee. His right leg extends backward, also bent 90 degrees at the knee and almost touching the ground. He is hunched over leaning on his left knee, standing on both sets of toes. He holds his book, presumably a Bible, in his right hand just next to his left knee, and his right arm hangs at his side, bent at the elbow with his hand resting on his left knee and his index finger pointing to a page in the book. His face is seen in profile, and he looks down at the book, reading. His long, curly hair falls back on his neck and over his left shoulder. His load extends over his shoulders, neck, and head. He is shoeless and wears a shirt and ragged pants or tights. Muscular thighs and buttocks are visible through his pants. Christian and Mr. Worldly-Wiseman stand on a flat, grassy stretch of ground, and a few layers of grassy hills rise behind them in the background toward the foot of the mountains. A few bushes or trees can be seen at the foot of the largest mountain and on the hill behind and to the right of Christian. A large, tall rock rises behind Mr. Worldly-Wiseman up to his waist, although it is mostly hidden from view. The background consists of three craggy mountains. The largest of these, in front of the others and at the right of the image, is particularly detailed with many crevices and ridges. Fire and smoke burst from its peak, suggesting that it is a volcano. This mountain is perhaps Mount Sinai.

desc.objtitle: Christian Fears the Fire from the Mountain, Object 8 (Butlin 829.8)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.8 states that the coloring is "mainly by [William] Blake but with some touching-up, for instance the ink outlines on the figure of Christian and the colouring of the flames." We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "8 Christian fears the flashes of fire from Mt Sinai" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christian stands on a multi-tiered rocky outcrop resembling two steps of a staircase, surrounded by flames and lightning. His body faces forward, and his head is turned slightly to his left, but forward enough that his face is still visible. His left foot is on the higher of the two rock steps, with the leg bent at the knee so that the lower leg is folded under his thigh. His right foot is on the lower rock step, with the leg extended. He stands poised on the toes of both feet. His arms are close to his sides, and bent at the elbow so that the forearms fold up against the upper arms. His hands are open, with fingers spread and palms flat facing forward, as if in a stance of surrender or shock. His mouth is slightly open, his slightly furrowed brow likewise portrays a shocked or fearful expression. His long, curly hair is parted in the middle and flows down both sides of his head, with the hair on his right side visibly flowing down his neck. He wears a skintight shirt and high-waisted, ragged knee-length pants or tights, revealing a muscular chest and thighs underneath. The bulge of his load is visible behind his right shoulder. The majority of the image is dominated by large tongues of flame and lightning. The most intense flames emanate from the top-right corner of the image, spreading down and to the left towards Christian, as well as along the top of the plate and down the left margin. Large, billowing clouds of smoke flow from the ends of the flames along the left margin and the bottom-right corner of the image. Two jagged bolts of lightning reach down from within the flames towards Christian in the middle of the image. The mountainside is visible behind the clouds of smoke in the bottom-right corner of the image. The mountain is presumably Mount Sinai.

desc.objtitle: Christian Falls at the Feet of Evangelist, Object 9 (Butlin 829.9)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.9 states that the design was "finished by another hand," presumably Catherine Blake's. We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal and verso inscriptions: "Xtian falls at the feet of Evangelist fearing the fire from Mt Sinai" below the design and with an illegible inscriptions on the verso ending with "...card mount".

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christian kneels in the center of the image, crouching hunched over completely so that his head is nearly touching the ground. He is shown in profile, viewed from his left side. He wears a tight-fitting shirt and tight, high-waisted pants or tights, revealing muscular arms and thighs. His leg is bent sharply at the knee, with knee on the ground, and lower leg tucked behind his thigh. The heel of his foot is wedged against his buttocks and stands on tiptoe, with the first two toes touching the ground. He is bent at the waist so that his torso is pressed against his thighs. The bulge of his load is prominent over his shoulders, and is secured to his body by a piece of fabric wrapped around his torso. The upper portion of his left arm hangs down to the ground, so that his elbow touches the ground. His arm is bent slightly at the elbow so that his forearm is stretched out along the surface of the ground, reaching towards the other figure. His hand is bent sharply at the wrist so that it stands up at a right angle from the forearm, fingers spread, and palms facing the other figure, touching his hands. Although his right arm is hidden behind his head and body, his right wrist and hand are visible, and in the same position as his left. His head hangs low between his arms, with his face hidden behind his left arm. His long, curly hair and crown of his head are visible, and the hair covers his neck. His position suggests supplication towards the other figure, as if asking for forgiveness. The other figure is an old male, presumably Evangelist. He wears a long, flowing gown that covers all but his head, hands, and right foot, although the gown is tight around the shoulders and arms, revealing a muscular physique underneath. He stands on the left side of the image, midstride in profile, with his right side visible. His right leg is forward, with the foot flat along the ground and visible poking out from under the hem of the gown. His left leg is extended behind him, and bent slightly at the knee. He is bent forward at the waist towards Christian below him. His arms reach down, with his hands touching Christian's hands. His left arm is mostly hidden behind his right, but the left hand and wrist are visible. He has long hair and beard, and his head is angled slightly so that both sides of his face are visible. His mouth is closed and he looks down at Christian, with his brows possibly furrowed in an expression of concern or consternation. The ground below both figures is level and grassy. The right side of the image is dominated by large, billowing, serpentine flames. They extend from the top-right corner diagonally down towards Christian at the center of the image. A tall stone or cliff face stands on the right edge of the image, though it is largely obscured by the flames above and in front of it. This is perhaps the foot of the volcanic mountain Mount Sinai. A large cloud of smoke extends across the top of the image from the flames to the left, curving behind Evangelist's back, and ending in a blunt point, resembling a jointed finger with the tip bent.

A tall stone or cliff face stands on the right edge of the image, though it is largely obscured by the flames above and in front of it. This is perhaps the foot of the volcanic mountain Mount Sinai.
A large cloud of smoke extends across the top of the image from the flames to the left, curving behind Evangelist's back, and ending in a blunt point, resembling a jointed finger with the tip bent.

desc.objtitle: Christian Knocks at the Wicket Gate, Object 10 (Butlin 829.10)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.10 states that "the figure of Christian, the wall to his left and the sky appear to have been worked over, though the rainbow effect on the right of the gate is probably [William] Blake's." We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. In addition to Blake's own inscription above the door in the design (see transcription), Butlin quotes the following marginal inscription: "10 Xtian knocks at the wicket gate" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christian stands in the middle of the image, knocking at a large gate set within a tall wall. He is shown in profile, midstride, with his right side to the viewer. His left leg is extended forward and bent at the knee, with the foot flat on the ground and a muscular calf. His right leg is extended backward on tiptoe, with only the first two toes touching the ground. He wears high-waisted, ragged pants or tights, although they are tight on the thighs, revealing a muscular physique. His right arm is extended forward, but bent 90 degrees at the elbow. The right hand holds the knocker of the gate. He wears a long-sleeved shirt, with clear folds in the fabric along his arms. The bulge of his load is prominent behind his right shoulder and head, and it is secured to his body by a piece of fabric wrapped around his torso. His long, curly hair flows down along his neck and shoulders. He faces right, looking up slightly at the knocker. The ground beneath him is flat and grassy, but a large stone or boulder sits to the left of him, against the wall. The gate is embedded into a tall wall that spans the width of the image. There is a tower, turret, or pilaster in the wall at the left edge of the image, with a drawn bow and arrow sitting atop it. The bow is aimed diagonally down and to the right at Christian. No clear figure holds the bow, although there are some indeterminate shapes that could be a figure. The gate, presumably the Wicket Gate, stands in the middle of the wall. It is tall and arched, with a point in the apex of the arch. The door of the gate is surrounded by a similarly arched and pointed doorframe, carved with faint vinelike shapes. The door itself has a large, ring-shaped knocker in the top-center, perhaps a sanctuary knocker, which Christian grabs. The bottom half of the door, below Christian's arm, is divided into three smaller carved arches, also with points, reminiscent of the Gothic style. The message "KNOCK AND IT SHALL BE OPENED" is carved into the edge of the door's arch. with the first three words on the left side, and the last three on the right. There is a small hole, perhaps a keyhole, in the right edge of the door, just below and to the right of Christian's elbow. A large, step sits at the foot of the gate. Behind the wall, a few steep rises of land can be seen. On the left, there is dark and leafy foliage, indicating trees or a forest. Behind this forest, the peak of a tall mountain can be seen, sloping down to the middle of the image. To the right of the forest, a steep road or path in the middle of the image leads to a small, square, flat-topped building with an open door. To the right of the path, a steep cliff topped with a line of dense bushy foliage--again suggesting trees--rises behind the wall. A large, round sun either rises or sets behind this forested cliff, with beams of sunlight reaching to the left across the top of the image towards the mountain and right towards the top-right corner. Dark streaks in the sky suggest clouds to the left of the sun.

lg.l: SHALLThis line and the following lines appear to be carved in an archlike shape onto a door with a knocker.

desc.objtitle: The Gate is Opened by Goodwill, Object 11(Butlin 829.11)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.11 implies that William Blake colored the design, "with only a few outlines touched in in [sic] ink by a later hand." We attribute the coloring to William Blake and the ink outlining to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "11 Good will opens the wicket gate to Xtian Christian returning home" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the center of the image, an old, male figure stands inside in open, arched doorway. The figure, presumably Goodwill, stands tall and with his body facing the viewer. He has long hair falling on either side of his face, and a long beard covering most of his chest and torso. His head is surrounded by a circular halo, and he stares directly forward, towards the viewer. He wears a long-sleeved gown that completely covers his body except for his head and hands. His left leg is visible beneath the gown, especially the kneecap and calf. His arms reach down towards the other figure in the image, Christian, with hands open, fingers spread, and palms facing away from the viewer, and one arm on either side of Christian as if embracing. Christian stands midstride as he climbs the steps towards the door and Goodwill. He is shown in profile facing right, with his left leg extended forward, bent at the knee, and the foot planted firmly at the top of the step at the foot of the door. His right leg extends backward, standing on tiptoe with only the first three toes on the ground below the step. He wears a long-sleeved shirt and high-waisted, ragged knee-length pants or tights, both tight-fitting so that a muscular physique is visible, especially at the shoulders and torso. His load bulges from behind his head, neck, and shoulders, and it is tied to him by a piece of fabric that wraps around his torso and also appears to wrap between his legs through the groin. He has long, curly hair flowing down his neck and shoulders. His head is tilted up and bent back so that he looks directly up at Goodwill’s face. Only his right arm is visible, and it is extended vertically, but with the forearm bent upward, reaching towards Goodwill in an embrace. His hand is open, fingers spread, with palm facing away from the viewer. The doorway that surrounds the two figures is arched in a Gothic style with a sharp point directly above Goodwill’s head. It is embedded in a wall, with a step at its base, which Christian climbs. The frame of the door is carved with twelve gowned figures, curving in serpentine curves, six on each side of the frame. Beams of light emanate from Goodwill and inside the door.

Only his right arm is visible, and it is extended vertically, but with the forearm bent upward, reaching towards Goodwill in an embrace. His hand is open, fingers spread, with palm facing away from the viewer.

The doorway that surrounds the two figures is arched in a Gothic style with a sharp point directly above Goodwill’s head. It is embedded in a wall, with a step at its base, which Christian climbs. desc.objtitle: The Man in the Iron Cage, Object 12 (Butlin 829.12)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.12 states that the design was "left very unfinished by [William] Blake but the cage heavily gone over in black and the figures touched-up" by another hand. We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "13 In the Interpreter's House—the rose[?] Page 20" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures stand on the left side of the image, with a third seated in a cage on the right side. The leftmost figure is presumably the Interpreter, and this room is therefore likely in the House of the Interpreter, featuring the cage of despair. He is seen in profile wearing a long, straight, long-sleeved gown, with only his head, hands, and feet uncovered. He has short, curly hair, and his head is angled downward slightly. He looks down towards the third figure in the cage on the right. His right arm is down at his side, bent at the elbow so that the hand and forearm are raised slightly. He holds two objects in this hand, one of which is clearly a key, the other being a bulb-shaped object at the end of a short shaft, possibly a second key. His feet are visible under the folded hem of his gown. The middle figure is Christian, and he stands with his body facing the viewer. His head is tilted slightly to his left and down, with long, curly hair flowing onto his shoulders. His face shows an expression of concern or despair. His eyes look down and to his left, towards the third figure in the cage. His mouth is perhaps slightly open. The bulge of his load is visible behind his head. He wears a tight-fitting long-sleeved shirt which reveals a muscular physique underneath. His arms are at his side, but bent at the elbow so his forearms and hands are raised. His fingers are spread, and his palms face away from the viewer. He wears high-waisted short pants or tights which are cut at the knees in a ragged hem. The pants are equally skintight, especially on his abdomen. He stands with his legs close together. His left leg is perhaps bent slightly at the knee, and the foot is turned out towards his left. The right leg, though seen head-on, is also perhaps bent slightly at the knee, as it appears that his heel is lifted off the ground, with his weight on his toes. The right side of the image is dominated by a giant cage enclosing the rightmost figure. The cage is as tall as Christian and the Interpreter, and about half as wide as it is tall. The cage is made of four vertical bars and five horizontal bars, with the middle horizontal bar broken in the middle so that there is a window for the prisoner’s face and upper body. The two ends of that bar end in large spikes, and the two horizontal bars above and below it also have vertical spikes reaching into the window. The intersections of the lower three horizontal bars and the middle two vertical bars also have large, circular bolts. There is a short vertical shaft in the middle of the cage above the prisoner’s head, but it does not extend the whole height of the cage. The figure in the cage is the aptly-named Man in the Iron Cage. He is seated with his body facing the viewer. His head is tilted slightly to his right, with his brows furrowed and his eyes looking down in an expression of despair. His hair is short and curly. He wears an iron collar around his neck. He wears no clothes, and his naked upper torso and shoulders are muscular. His arms hang at his sides close to his body, with his hands at his feet. His knees and legs cover his lower torso. His legs are crossed with his right over his left. He has prominent toes, and his feet appear to be raised so that he is on tiptoe. He wears shackles around his ankles, with links of chain hanging from both. He appears to be clasping the chains of his left foot with his right hand. The walls of the room can be seen behind the figures and the cage and are made of large stone blocks.

The Man in the Iron Cage is chained and shackled. He wears an iron collar around his neck. He wears shackles around his ankles, with links of chain hanging from both. He appears to be clasping the chains of his left foot with his right hand.
The walls of the room in the House of the Interpreter can be seen behind the figures and the cage and are made of large stone blocks.

desc.objtitle: The Man Who Dreamed of the Day of Judgment, Object 13 (Butlin 829.13)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.13 states that "both figures and setting have been heavily gone over [by another hand] to produce a finished watercolour, though the granular treatment of the flesh may be [William] Blake's." We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "14" altered from "13" followed by "Mr Interpreter shows him the man who had the dream of the Day of Judgement" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two figures stand looking at a third figure sitting on a bed. The rightmost figure is Christian. He stands fully erect, seen in profile, but with a slight angling towards the viewer so that his chest is seen. His head, in full profile, is bent down slightly as he looks at the seated figure below and to the left. His brow is furrowed slightly. His long, curly hair flows behind his neck onto his left shoulder. The bulge of his load is visible behind his left shoulder as well. The load is secured to his body by two straps running diagonally from his shoulders down under his armpits, crossing over his chest. He wears a tight-fitting, long-sleeved shirt which reveals a muscular physique underneath, particularly for left shoulder and arm. His left arm is fully visible, while only his right hand, wrist, and the end of the sleeve can be seen, with the rest of that arm hidden behind his chest. The left arm is down at his side but bent at the elbow so that the forearm extends forward. Both hands are raised upward, with palms facing out and fingers spread. He wears high-waisted and equally skintight short pants or tights, which are cut at the knee with a ragged him and have large, ragged holes on the thighs. His legs are together, with the left leg straight and the right leg bent back slightly at the knee, so that the right foot rests on tiptoe. The middle figure, partly obscured behind Christian, is the Interpreter. He stands facing the viewer, wearing a long, loose gown covering all but his hands and head. His head is tilted slightly to his right and bent down, and he looks down towards the seated third figure at his right. He is an old man, with curly hair and beard. His right arm is fully visible, down at his side, but bent at the elbow so that the forearm crosses over his torso. His right hand is bent down, folded over his left wrist, and partially hidden behind Christian’s right hand. All that is visible of his left arm is the hand, which is crossed over his torso and pointing towards the third figure, with his other fingers folded in. The leftmost figure is the Man Who Dreamed of the Day of Judgment. He is seated on a low bed, facing the viewer. His head is titled slightly to his left, and he looks up and to the right towards Christian and the Interpreter. His mouth is slightly open, and he is possibly speaking of his dream. His long, curly hair falls behind his shoulders. He wears a long, long-sleeved gown which is tight around his chest and arms, revealing a muscular physique underneath. His arms are down at his sides, but bent at the elbow so that the forearms are straight out towards the viewer, resting on his legs. His hands are clenched in fists resting on his knees. He is seated with his legs together and drawn up, bent at the knee. The gown falls in loose folds on either side and behind the legs, but leaves them uncovered. His feet, with prominent toes, are touching and are flat on the floor. Behind the seated figure, a large blanket or other bed covering is mounded up on the length of the far side of the bed, but flows down over the edge of the bed to the floor as well. To the left of the image, a large, white pillow can be seen at the head of the bed. A large, billowing curtain surrounds the bed, with one side drawn up and hanging along the left edge of the image. Behind Christian and the Interpreter is the stone wall of the room, with a clear stack of carved stone blocks at the right edge of the image, and three vertical posts or wall corners visible, perhaps indicating a doorway or other opening into the room.

desc.objtitle: Christian Before the Cross, Object 14 (Butlin 829.14)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.14 states that the design, presumably including the coloring, is "entirely by [William] Blake apart from some possible reinforcement in the dark blues." We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "15 Christian's burden falls off at Sight of the Cross—" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christian stands slightly right of the center of the image. He is turned facing away from the viewer, but with his head turned to his left so it is seen in profile. He has long, curly hair flowing down his neck to the top of his back. His head is titled back slightly so that he can look up to the figure of Christ above him. He wears a tight-fitting shirt, revealing a muscular physique underneath. He also wears high-waisted pants or tights, equally skintight, particularly around his lower back and buttocks. The pants cut off at the knee in a ragged hem. Both arms are bent at the elbow and folded up on themselves, so that the forearms and hands are raised. His left arm is close to his side, while the right arm is held slightly away from the body. His hands are raised, palms facing out away from the viewer, with fingers spread. His legs are together; however, his left foot is planted with the weight on the toes and heel raised, so the left leg must be extended slightly behind the right. His right foot is planted flat on the ground. At his feet on the ground to his left is a large, round, stone-shaped object, presumably his load which has been released from his back. A few tongues of flame envelop the load. Above Christian in the top-center of the image is a vision of a figure, presumably Christ. He is just a partial figure, with just his head, chest, torso, and upper arms visible, with other body parts fading into the clouds that surround him. He faces the viewer with arms raised horizontally and outstretched as if crucified. His head is tilted down and slightly to his left, so that he looks down upon Christian below him. His long hair is parted and flows down both sides of his face and onto his arm on his left side. There are perhaps faint outlines of a beard on his face. Christ is surrounded by billowing, smoky clouds, and sharp, almost spikelike protrusions, perhaps beams of light, extend from the lower portions of the cloud, six on either side of Christ. They are perhaps beams of light. The ground in front of Christian forms a grassy mound. A tree stands at the top of this mound, partially obscured by Christian, and extending up towards Christ and merging into his torso, forming the vertical post of the visionary cross on which Christ is crucified. The tree is covered in serpentine, leafy vines resembling ivy which wrap around the trunk and extend into the clouds and spiky beams of light, particularly on the right side of the image. There are two vertical, thin posts on either side of the tree at the edges of the image, with serpentine ivy vines winding up their height to as well. The roots of the tree and the lower ivy vines are covered in tongues of flame. There is a door-like opening at the bottom-left side of the mound, framed by a trilithon-shaped doorframe. The dark interior of a cave within the mound can be seen through the door. This cave is presumably Christ's tomb. The sky behind the tree, the ivy-covered posts, and the clouds with the vision of Christ is filled with even darker billowing clouds or smoke.

component.illusobjdesc: Christian stands slightly right of the center of the image. He is turned facing away from the viewer, but with his head turned to his left so it is seen in profile. He has long, curly hair flowing down his neck to the top of his back. His head is titled back slightly so that he can look up to the figure of Christ above him. He wears a tight-fitting shirt, revealing a muscular physique underneath. He also wears high-waisted pants or tights, equally skintight, particularly around his lower back and buttocks. The pants cut off at the knee in a ragged hem. Both arms are bent at the elbow and folded up on themselves, so that the forearms and hands are raised. His left arm is close to his side, while the right arm is held slightly away from the body. His hands are raised, palms facing out away from the viewer, with fingers spread. His legs are together; however, his left foot is planted with the weight on the toes and heel raised, so the left leg must be extended slightly behind the right. His right foot is planted flat on the ground. At his feet on the ground to his left is a large, round, stone-shaped object, presumably his load which has been released from his back. A few tongues of flame envelop the load.

Christian stands slightly right of the center of the image. At his feet on the ground to his left is a large, round, stone-shaped object, presumably his load which has been released from his back. A few tongues of flame envelop the load.

Above Christian in the top-center of the image is a vision of a figure, presumably Christ. He is just a partial figure, with just his head, chest, torso, and upper arms visible, with other body parts fading into the clouds that surround him. He faces the viewer with arms raised horizontally and outstretched as if crucified. His head is tilted down and slightly to his left, so that he looks down upon Christian below him. His long hair is parted and flows down both sides of his face and onto his arm on his left side. There are perhaps faint outlines of a beard on his face. Christ is surrounded by billowing, smoky clouds, and sharp, almost spikelike protrusions extend from the lower portions of the cloud, six on either side of Christ. They are perhaps beams of light.

Christ is surrounded by billowing, smoky clouds, and sharp, almost spikelike protrusions, perhaps beams of light, extend from the lower portions of the cloud, six on either side of Christ. They are perhaps beams of light.
The ground in front of Christian forms a grassy mound.
The ground in front of Christian forms a grassy mound.

The ground in front of Christian forms a grassy mound. A tree stands at the top of this mound, partially obscured by Christian, and extending up towards Christ and merging into his torso, forming the vertical post of the visionary cross on which Christ is crucified. The tree is covered in leafy, serpentine vines resembling ivy which wrap around the trunk and extend into the clouds and spiky beams of light, particularly on the right side of the image. The roots of the tree and the lower ivy vines are covered in tongues of flame.

The tree on which Christ is crucified is covered in leafy, serpentine vines resembling ivy which wrap around the trunk and extend into the clouds and spiky beams of light, particularly on the right side of the image. The roots of the tree and the lower ivy vines are covered in tongues of flame.
The roots of the tree,the lower ivy vines, and Christian's load are covered in tongues of flame.
There are two vertical, thin posts on either side of the tree at the edges of the image, with serpentine ivy vines winding up their height.
There are two vertical, thin posts on either side of the tree at the edges of the image, with serpentine ivy vines winding up their height.

The ground in front of Christian forms a grassy mound. There is a door-like opening at the bottom-left side of the mound, framed by a trilithon-shaped doorframe. The dark interior of a cave within the mound can be seen through the door. This cave is presumably Christ's tomb.
The sky behind the tree, the ivy-covered posts, and the clouds with the vision of Christ is filled with even darker billowing clouds or smoke.

desc.objtitle: Christian Met by the Three Shining Ones, Object 15 (Butlin 829.15)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.15 states that there is "some touching-up [by another hand] on Christian's outlines; also the mauve edge of the leading Shining One's wing." We attribute most of the coloring to Catherine Blake, but the blue sky may have been colored by William Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "16 Page 23 The Shining Ones appear to Christian" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The image is dominated by four figures: Christian and three angels. Christian is the rightmost figure. He stands facing the viewer, but with his body turned away slightly so that we see him at an angle. His head is tilted so that his whole face is visible. His long, curly hair flows down his neck onto his shoulders. His eyes are open wide as if in fear or surprise. He looks forward and down, as if looking at a point on the ground between him and the viewer. He wears a long, loose, long-sleeved gown covering all of his body except his head, hands, and feet. His left arm is fully visible, and hangs down close to his side, but bent at the elbow so that his forearm crosses over his chest and torso. His hand hangs down slightly. His right arm is hidden behind his body except for the hand, which holds a long, skinny rod, his walking stick or staff. His legs are together, with the right leg straight and the foot planted flat on the ground. His left leg is bent slightly back at the knee, with the heel raised and foot standing on tip toe. A tall, skinny post stands behind Christian at the right edge of the image. A serpentine, leafy, ivy-like vine wraps around the entire height of the post. The next figure to the left is an angel standing in profile facing right, but with head turned facing the viewer. Slightly pronounced breasts suggest that this figure is female. She has long, curly hair which falls behind her neck. Her facial features are vague, but she appears to be looking towards the viewer and her mouth may be slightly open. Her head is surrounded by a halo. Her right arm is fully visible and raised towards Christian’s head. She touches Christian’s forehead with her pointer finger, and all other fingers folded into the hand. Her left arm is mostly hidden behind her body, except her hand at her thigh, holding an object which appears to be an unrolled scroll. She wears a loose, transparent gown. Her legs are together, with her left leg straight and foot planted flat on the ground. Her right leg is bent back slightly at the knee, with the heel raised and foot standing on tip toe. Her large, right wing is folded up close to her body, with a few individual feathers visible. The next angel to the left faces the viewer head-on. She wears a long, transparent gown, with slightly pronounced breasts suggesting that she is female. Her head is turned and tilted slightly to her left. Her long hair falls behind her neck and shoulders. Her head is surrounded by a halo. Her arms both hang down at her sides. Her hands hold some indeterminate objects. They are loose, flowery, ragged or leafy shapes, perhaps Christian’s old ragged clothes. Her legs are together, but crossed so that the right leg is in front of the left and the calf and foot of the left leg are hidden. Her wings are folded on both sides behind her, but with their top curve prominent on both sides of her head, and a few feathers visible. The leftmost angel stands facing the viewer head-on. She wears a long, transparent gown, with slightly pronounced breasts suggesting that she is female. Her head is turned and tilted slightly to her right and down, and she appears to be looking down, reading a book held in one hand. Long, curly hair, flows down behind her neck and shoulder. Her head is surrounded by a halo. Her left arm is down close to her side, but bent at the elbow so that the forearm and hand are raised. Her hand is not clear, but appears to be bent back towards her body. Her right arm is also down close to her side, but bent at the elbow so that the forearm crosses over her torso. Resting on the forearm and hand is an open book. Her legs are together, with the left leg straight and foot planted flat on the ground. Her right leg is bent back slightly at the knee, with the heel raised and foot standing on tip toe. Her wings are folded on both sides behind her, but with their top curve prominent on both sides of her head, and a few feathers visible. Her right wing is fully visible, but her left wing is partially obscured by the middle angel’s right wing. At the far left edge of the image, a few leafy branches reach up from the ground to about waist height of the figures. The branches have long, flame or tongue-shaped leaves, perhaps a laurel. The figures stand on a flat, grassy ground. A few lines in the space beneath the left bush suggest a stone or other indeterminate object. Beams of light emanate from the angels into the sky above, most visible from the left and right angels. A thin, dark cloud runs along the upper margin extending from the middle angel and becoming darker and slightly more billowing as it reaches towards Christian.

desc.objtitle: Christian Climbs the Hill Difficulty, Object 16 (Butlin 829.16)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.16 states that the design, presumably including the coloring, is "largely by [William] Blake though ink outlines probably added" by another hand. We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscription: "17 Christian climbs the Hill Difficulty" below the design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the middle of the image, Christian climbs up the side of steep cliff, the Hill of Difficulty. He stands facing away, with his back to the viewer. He wears a long, loose, semi-transparent gown, revealing a muscular physique underneath, especially on his back and buttocks. His arms are fully extended vertically above his head, reaching for the top of the cliff. His hands hold onto the top, and he attempts to pull himself up. His head is up, bent back, and turned so that we see his face in profile. His eyes are raised so that he looks up to the top of the cliff, with brows furrowed and mouth slightly open, in an expression of exhaustion or despair. His long, curly hair flows down his neck onto his upper back between his shoulders. His left leg is fully extended, with the foot flat on a rock. His right leg is partially hidden by his torso, but is visibly drawn up and bent at the knee climbing up another higher rock, with the foot planted flat. He has many small, bloody scrapes and cuts all over his body. The cliff is a solid, stone face dominating most of the image. It has several grooves and cracks, with large boulders or rocks at the bottom of the cliff. The top of the cliff curves down in the middle, forming a serpentine ridge. It is this lower dip in the middle which Christian clings to and climbs. There is a noticeably smooth path or road through the middle of this cliff. On the left side of the image, a gently sloping hill runs right to the edge of the cliff, which falls suddenly down, calling to mind the cliffs of Dover, although with reverse coloration as the hill is white and the rocks dark. Two leafless, thorny vines grow on the rocks of the cliff, one along the bottom edge of the image, growing in a serpentine but generally horizontal pattern. The other grows vertically on the left edge of the image. At the right edge of the image, another small, indeterminate shrub grows, possibly a laurel. It has two thin, vertical branches covered in long, thin, pointed leaves, shaped like tongues or flames. The plant bears several small, round, berry-like fruits and/or flowers. A double-gabled indeterminate building sits at the top of the cliff in the distance, perhaps the arbor which Christian will reach in the next illustration. It is simply constructed of vertical walls with a triangular, pointed roof. It has no door, but is open on the side facing the viewer so that the interior can be seen. A low, horizontal object spans the length of the interior, perhaps a bench. The second gable is visible behind the first. An indeterminate, rectangular object or structure stands to the right of the building, obscured behind the right side of the cliff face. It resembles a tall, vertical stone or boulder, such as a menhir.

On the left side of the image, a gently sloping hill runs right to the edge of the cliff, which falls suddenly down, calling to mind the cliffs of Dover, although with reverse coloration as the hill is white and the rocks dark.

At the right edge of the image, a small, indeterminate shrub grows, possibly a laurel. It has two thin, vertical branches covered in long, thin, pointed leaves, shaped like tongues or flames. The plant bears several small, round, berry-like fruits and/or flowers.

It is simply constructed of vertical walls with a triangular, pointed roof. It has no door, but is open on the side facing the viewer so that the interior can be seen. A low, horizontal object spans the length of the interior, perhaps a bench. The second gable is visible behind the first.

An indeterminate, rectangular object or structure stands to the right of the building, obscured behind the right side of the cliff face. It resembles a tall, vertical stone or boulder, such as a menhir.

desc.objtitle: Christian in the Arbour, Object 17 (Butlin 829.17)

objnote.p: Butlin 829.17 states that the design was "finished by [William] Blake with the exception of the rainbow which seems to have been reinforced by another hand." We attribute most, possibly all, of the coloring to Catherine Blake. Butlin also quotes the following marginal inscriptions: "18" top right, "Page 26/18" below the design, and "Christian in the Arbour" on the modern mount.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Christian rests at an arbor resembling a gazebo or small hut, but constructed from and covered in vegetation. The arbor is simply constructed, with three vertical sides forming and a triangular, pointed roof. There is no fourth wall or door, so that the arbor is open and the interior fully visible. The four corners of the walls are made from the trunks of trees that appear to be palms, with a fifth tree in the center of the structure supporting the roof, although the back right corner is obscured by Christian. The center and back-left trunks have the distinct scaly bark characteristic of palms, and while the front two do not have such visible bark, the long, thin, fronds branching from the tops of all suggest that they are all palms. A few palm branches are bent down and hang from the tops of the trees, resembling folded wings. However, the majority of the palm branches grow upwards to form the roof of the arbor. A thin vine winds around the bottom half of the central palm, with large, round flowers or fruits growing on it. The bottom half of the back-left palm is also covered in similar fruits or flowers, but the vine from which they grow is not visible. A large, fully blooming flower sits at the point of the roof, with its own large, thin, leafy branches growing downwards merging with the palm branches to complete the roof. The flower has at least two tear-shaped petals, and three prominent stamens, pistils, or other vertical protrusions. The leaves of the flower greatly resemble those of the palm trees. The two front palm trees are covered in other indeterminate vining vegetation that wraps around the trunks. These vines have thin, tongue or flame-shaped leaves shorter than those of the palms. The back wall of the arbor is covered in similar vegetation, most visible between the back-left and center palms, but growing as vertical shrubs with freestanding branches instead of vines growing on supports. The leaves are also thin and tongue or flame-shaped, suggesting that these are possibly the same plant, perhaps a laurel. A few similarly-shaped leaves are visible behind Christian’s left leg in the back-right corner of the arbor as well. Another similar but smaller bush grows behind the front-right palm tree, around that corner of the arbor on the outside. This exterior bush has lumps of fruit or flowers growing at its base, similar to those at the bases of the palm trees. A low, horizontal stone bench or pew is built along all three walls of the arbor. It has carvings on its sides, most prominent on the portions of the bench along the left wall and under Christian’s left knee. The top of the bench is covered in a slimy semi-solid liquid, which appears to be crushed fruits from the various plants within the arbor. Christian sits on the right side of the bench, blocking the view of most of the interior of that side of the arbor. He faces the viewer, wearing a long, semi-transparent, long-sleeved gown which reveals a muscular physique underneath, especially on his arms, chest, and legs. His head is held up, but tilted slightly to his left. His long hair falls just above his shoulders. His mouth is open, and his brows are furrowed slightly, indicating an expression of exhaustion or concern. His eyes are raised and he looks up. His left arm is raised vertically, fully extended as if reaching for the sky. The hand is raised and open, with fingers spread and palm facing out towards the viewer. His right arm hangs straight down by his side, close to his body. It is fully extended downward, and in his hand he holds a rolled scroll. He sits with his legs spread. His right leg is straight and extended out to the right, with the foot resting flat on the ground. His left thigh rests on the bench, but the leg is bent at the knee so that the lower leg reaches down to the ground, with his foot on tiptoe and heel raised. His body is covered in small, bloody scrapes or cuts. The ground below the arbor and Christian is covered in grass, with individual leaves especially noticeable at the bottom-left corner of the image. The arbor sits atop a hill, as indicated by a downward slope in the ground at the bottom-right corner of the image. A path or road runs the width of the image just below Christian and the bench, separating the thin patch of grass along the bottom margin of the image from that underneath the arbor and Christian. A large rainbow fills the sky above the arbor, spreading across the entire width of the image.
